Problem:
Consider a system characterized by the integral equation \\( y(t) = \\int_0^t e^{(t-s)A}x(s) \\, ds \\), where A is a constant matrix. We study the effect of applying a transformation \\( f(x) = e^{Bt}x(t) \\) over time t, where B is another constant matrix.

If a new function \\( g(x) = e^{Ct}x(t) \\) (where C is a constant matrix) is applied as an intervention at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), will the endpoint \\( y(T) \\) for T > t_1 still purely depend on the initial function \\( x(t) \\) and matrix A, disregarding matrices B and C?
Explanation: The intervention introduces a new transformation, adding another layer of complexity. The endpoint \\( y(T) \\) will now depend on how the transformations \\( e^{Bt} \\) and \\( e^{Ct} \\) altered \\( x(t) \\) along with the effects dictated by A. This influences the entire integration process from \\( t_1 \\) to T.
